Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story:
I stared at the calendar, my finger tracing the days leading up to the family holiday. Every year, I’m the one who gathers everyone together, the one who calls, who bakes, who listens to stories and laughter echoing through the house. My daughter had already texted, “Can’t wait to see you, Mom!” and my grandson sent a drawing of us holding hands. I felt the warmth of their expectations, the comfort of tradition.

But on my desk, the lab schedule glared back at me. The experiment I’d been planning for months was finally ready. The equipment was booked, the samples prepped, and the data I could collect during this window might be the breakthrough I’d been chasing. My team was counting on me to lead, to be present, to push the boundaries of what we know.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My heart ached at the thought of missing the holiday, of disappointing my family. Yet, the thrill of discovery tugged at me, the responsibility to my colleagues and to science itself. I sat in silence, torn between the warmth of home and the call of the unknown, unsure which part of myself to honor.
